title: 114_s3092
content: The Act titled "Fair Access to Investment Research Act of 2016" provides a safe harbor for investment fund research. The Securities and Exchange Commission will propose revisions to provide a safe harbor for covered investment fund research reports published by brokers or dealers. The Securities and Exchange Commission will propose revisions to provide a safe harbor for covered investment fund research reports published by brokers or dealers. The safe harbor allows brokers or dealers to sell a security subject to an effective registration statement, even if they are participating in the offering of the fund's securities. The Commission will implement the safe harbor without conditioning it on the continuous distribution of a fund's securities. The Securities and Exchange Commission will propose revisions to provide a safe harbor for covered investment fund research reports published by brokers or dealers. The safe harbor conditions on whether the broker's or dealer's publication or distribution of a covered investment fund research report constitutes their initiation or reinitiation of research coverage on the fund or its securities. It does not require the fund to have been registered as an investment company or subject to reporting requirements for any period exceeding the specified time. The proposed revisions by the Securities and Exchange Commission aim to provide a safe harbor for covered investment fund research reports published by brokers or dealers. The revisions include conditions that prevent self-regulatory organizations from imposing certain restrictions on members related to publishing or distributing such reports. The Securities and Exchange Commission's proposed revisions aim to create a safe harbor for covered investment fund research reports. These reports are exempt from certain regulations under the Investment Company Act of 1940, but may still be subject to content standards set by self-regulatory organizations. The Act does not limit the application of antifraud provisions of Federal securities laws to covered investment fund research reports, nor does it limit the authority of self-regulatory organizations to supervise member practices related to such reports. From 180 days after the enactment of the Act, if the Commission has not revised section 230.139 of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations, a broker or dealer can rely on this section when distributing a covered investment fund research report. After 180 days from the Act's enactment, a broker or dealer can rely on section 230.139 of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations for distributing a covered investment fund research report. A covered investment fund meeting reporting requirements will be considered a security listed on a national securities exchange until regulatory revisions are made. A covered investment fund research report is a report about a covered investment fund or its securities published by a broker or dealer. Communications about covered investment funds falling under specific regulations do not need to be filed with FINRA. An investment company registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and the Securities Act of 1933, or a trust issuing securities listed on a national securities exchange. An investment company or trust listed on a national securities exchange that primarily deals in commodities, currencies, or derivative instruments. The term "FINRA" refers to the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, and a "research report" excludes oral communications as defined under the Securities Act of 1933. The term "self-regulatory organization" is defined under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and excludes oral communications.
